{{EngvarB|date=November 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2017}} {{Infobox artist | honorific_prefix = | name = Ajamu X<!-- include middle initial, if not specified in birth_name --> | honorific_suffix = | image =<!-- just the pagename, without the File:/Image: prefix or [[brackets]] --> | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different than name --> | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1963}} <!-- {{Birth date and age|df=yes|YYYY|MM|DD}} for living artists, {{Birth date|df=yes|YYYY|MM|DD}} for dead. For living people supply only the year unless the exact date is already WIDELY published, as per [[WP:DOB]]. Treat such cases as if only the year is known, so use {{birth year and age|YYYY}} or a similar option. --> | birth_place = [[Huddersfield|Huddersfield, UK]] | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|df=yes|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | death_place = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | nationality = British | residence = | education = | alma_mater = | known_for = | notable_works = | style = | movement = | spouse = | partner = | awards = <!-- {{awd|award|year|title|role|name}} (optional) --> | elected = | patrons = | memorials = | website = {{URL|ajamu-fineartphotography.co.uk}} | module = }}
'''Ajamu X''' (born 1963 in [[Huddersfield]]) is a British artist, curator, archivist and activist. He best known for his fine art photography, which explores same-sex desire and the Black male body, and his work as an archivist and activist to document the lives and experiences of black [[LGBTQ]] people in the UK.
==Early life== Ajamu was born in 1963 in [[Huddersfield]] to [[Jamaicans|Jamaican]] parents. His grandparents arrived to England in 1958 and his parents followed in 1962.<ref name="GuardianTnt">{{cite news|last1=Surtees|first1=Joshua|title=Ajamu challenges homophobia|url=http://www.guardian.co.tt/lifestyle/2014-07-24/ajamu-challenges-homophobia|accessdate=29 June 2017|work=Guardian Trinidad and Tobago|date=25 July 2014}}</ref>
Ajamu came out as gay to his parents in his late teens and describes their reaction as "impressively progressive for the times".<ref name="GuardianTnt"/> He studied Black History and photography in [[Leeds]]. While in Leeds he and two friends, created the magazine ''BLAC'', an acronym for Black Liberation Activist Core. In October 1987, after seeing it advertised in the newspaper ''[[Caribbean Times]]'', Ajamu attended the first, and only, National Black Gay Men's Conference held at the [[Black Lesbian and Gay Centre]] in Camden. By January the following year, he had moved to London.<ref name="AjamuXInt2008">{{cite web|title=Ajamu X interview|url=http://www.samthewheels.co.uk/2008-interviews-volunteers/450|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170815010101/http://www.samthewheels.co.uk/2008%2Dinterviews%2Dvolunteers/450|website=Sam The Wheels|accessdate=13 April 2016|dead-url=yes|archivedate=2008}}</ref><ref name="Cook2014">{{cite book|last1=Cook|first1=Matt|title=Queer Domesticities: Homosexuality and Home Life in Twentieth-Century London|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EHOEAwAAQBAJ|date=2014|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|isbn=978-1-137-31607-3}}</ref> He was given the name Ajamu in 1991; it means "he who fights for what he believes".<ref name="GuardianTnt" />
{{Quote|text=My name Ajamu X is a reference to [[Malcolm X]] who was my first key role model. Changing my name to an African one was very significant. |author=Ajamu X<ref name="AjamuXInt2008" />}}
== Career == Ajamu's work often highlights stories of black [[LGBT]] individuals who he feels are often marginalised from mainstream British Society; additionally he has chosen to focus on those who are black and openly "out" and have been accepted by their families. Ajamu has said he rejects the claim that Jamaican culture is particularly homophobic and believes that homophobia exists across cultures and families of all backgrounds.<ref name="GuardianTnt" />
He often speaks of his work as a "sex activist"; he has run "sex parties for men who want to have sex with men" since the 1990s,<ref name="GuardianTnt" /> and same-sex desire and pleasure are recurring themes in his photography. His first major exhibition ''Black Bodyscapes'', in 1994, focused on the private sexual realities of black gay men.<ref name="OpenEye2014">{{cite web|last1=Seery |first1=Emma |title=Ajamu: Sexual Idenitifcation |url=http://www.openeye.org.uk/2014/03/4489/ |website=Open Eye Gallery |accessdate=2 December 2015 |date=28 March 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304085336/http://www.openeye.org.uk/2014/03/4489/ |archivedate=4 March 2016 }}</ref> More recent projects include ''Fierce: Portraits of Young Black Queers''. an exhibition of 24 portraits of a "…new generation of Black and proudly out young, emerging and established talent"<ref name="Afropunk2013">{{cite web|last1=Minott|first1=Zinzi|title=Fierce and That: Pondering the Work of Ajamu X an Original Afropunk|url=http://www.afropunk.com/profiles/blogs/fierce-and-that-ponderings-on-the-work-of-ajamu-x-an-original|website=AfroPunk|accessdate=2 December 2015|date=27 March 2013}}</ref> at London's [[Guildhall Art Gallery]] in 2014<ref name="OpenDem 2014Nov" /> and ''I Am For You Can Enjoy''<ref name="ContactTheatre2016" /> with Khalil West, at [[Contact Theatre]], Manchester, in 2016, which uses photography and video, to explore the lives of [[queer]] Black male sex workers and their clients. Ajamu has described himself as an "artist who has created an rchive"<ref name="Vincent2014">{{cite book|last1=Vincent|first1=John|title=LGBT People and the UK Cultural Sector: The Response of Libraries, Museums, Archives and Heritage since 1950|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=a1i8AgAAQBAJ|date=28 February 2014|publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd.|isbn=978-1-4724-0331-5|page=3}}</ref> and, in addition to his art practice, continues to document black LGBT experiences. {{Quote|text=Write and record everything you do; no-one is going to write our histories for us. |author=Ajamu X<ref name="OpenDem 2014Nov">{{cite web|last1=X|first1=Zia|title=What is it to be Fierce? The photography of Ajamu|url=https://www.opendemocracy.net/transformation/zia-x/what-is-it-to-be-fierce-photography-of-ajamu|website=Open Democracy|accessdate=2 December 2015|date=November 2014}}</ref>}}
In 2000 Ajamu and [[Topher Campbell]] co-founded ''rukus! Federation''<ref name="LMA2015">{{cite web|title=Love and lubrication in the archives: rukus! Black Lesbian Gay Bisexual Transgender Cultural Archive catalogue launched|url=http://www.cityoflondon.gov.uk/things-to-do/london-metropolitan-archives/the-collections/Pages/rukus.aspx|website=London Metropolitan Archives|publisher=City of London|accessdate=13 April 2016|year=2015}}</ref> an " arts company dedicated to celebrating and showcasing the best in challenging, provocative works by black lesbian, gay, bisexual and trans-gender artists nationally and internationally."<ref name="AjamuXInt2008" /> Ajamu was the Archive Manager "The Black LGBT Archive Project", a major initiative to develop an archive collection on "Black Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Trans-Gender heritage, history and lived experience in the UK".<ref name="AjamuXInt2008" /> In 2008 Ajamu co-curated the exhibition ''Outside Edge: a journey through Black lesbian and gay history'' at the [[Museum of Docklands]].<ref name="MoL2008" /> The ''rukus! Black Lesbian Gay Bisexual Transgender Cultural Archive'' was deposited at [[London Metropolitan Archives]] in 2010.<ref name=RunnymedeJun2011>{{cite journal|last1= |first1=Ajamu|title=Celebrating History|journal=Runnymede Bulletin|date=June 2011|issue=366|page=26|url=http://www.runnymedetrust.org/uploads/bulletin/pdfs/366-BulletinSummer11W.pdf|accessdate=2 December 2015}}</ref>
Ajamu was the subject of Topher Campbell's first film ''The Homecoming: A Short Film about Ajamu'' in 1995''.''<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=VfdpdZ9DwH0C&pg=PA9|title=Companion to Contemporary Black British Culture|last=Donnell|first=Alison|date=11 September 2002|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781134700257|language=en}}</ref> The documentary film ''Brixton Recreation with Ajamu,'' directed by Danny Solle, featured his experiences of cruising and sex as a out Black gay man in Brixton.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=0FASDQAAQBAJ&pg=PA80&lpg=PA80&dq=ajamu+%22brixton+recreation%22&source=bl&ots=riWaVh3TLD&sig=5tOqgKwncWZFpWSgyfo0_d4LVzs&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjfiJ_K7pzUAhVrLcAKHWckDV8Q6AEIMzAD#v=onepage&q=ajamu%20%22brixton%20recreation%22&f=false|title=Sex, Time and Place: Queer Histories of London, c.1850 to the Present|last=Avery|first=Simon|last2=Graham|first2=Katherine M.|date=6 October 2016|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|isbn=9781474234948|language=en}}</ref>
His fine art photography is in national and international collections including the [[Gallery of Modern Art, Glasgow|Gallery of Modern Art]] in Glasgow, [[Autograph ABP]], and the [[Neuberger Museum of Art]] in New York. Ajamu is co-chair of Centred, an LGBTQ community organisation, in London's Soho.<ref name=CentredTrustees>{{cite web|title=Trustees, Centred|url=http://www.centred.org.uk/content/about-centred/trustees|website=Centred|accessdate=2 December 2015}}</ref>
==Selected exhibitions== * 2016 ''Khalil West and Ajamu - I Am For You Can Enjoy'', [[Contact Theatre]], Manchester (4 February - 18 June 2016)<ref name="ContactTheatre2016">{{cite web|title=Khalil West and Ajamu - ''I Am For You Can Enjoy''|url=http://contactmcr.com/whats-on/exhibition/27-qc2016-ajamu-and-khalil-west-i-am-for-you-can-enjoy/|website=Contact Theatre|accessdate=13 April 2016}}</ref> * 2013 ''Fierce - Portraits of Young Black LGBTQ people by Ajamu'', Guildhall Art Gallery, London * 2012 ''Future Histories'', Street Level Photoworks, Glasgow * 2011 ''Queer Self Portraits Now'', Fred, London<ref name="Artlyst2011">{{cite web|title=''Queer Self Portraits Now''|url=http://www.artlyst.com/events/queer-self-portraits-now-fred-london|website=Artlyst|accessdate=13 April 2016}}</ref> * 2010 ''Photoshow'', [[Leslie-Lohman Museum of Gay and Lesbian Art]], New York * 2009 ''Familiar Strangers'', [[Gallery of Modern Art, Glasgow|Gallery of Modern Art]], Glasgow * 2004 ''Hidden Histories'', Walsall New Art Gallery,England * 1997 ''Transforming the Crown'', Caribbean Cultural Centre, New York.<ref name="Chambers2014">{{cite book|author=Eddie Chambers|title=Black Artists in British Art: A History since the 1950s|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OfBeBAAAQBAJ|date=29 July 2014|publisher=I.B.Tauris|isbn=978-0-85773-608-6}}</ref> * 1994 ''Black Bodyscapes'', Camerawork, London<ref name="RecordingKeen1996">{{cite book|author1=Melanie Keen|author2=Elizabeth Ward|author3=Institute of International Visual Arts|title=Recordings: a select bibliography of contemporary African, Afro-Caribbean and Asian British art|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RU_rAAAAMAAJ|year=1996|publisher=Institute of International Visual Arts and Chelsea College of Art and Design|isbn=978-1-899846-06-1|page=44}}</ref> * 1992 ''From Where I Stand'', Brixton Art Gallery, London<ref name=RecordingKeen1996 />
As Curator: * 2016 ''Curatorial Resident'', Visual AIDS, New York<ref name="VisualAIDS">{{cite web|title=Introducing 2016 Visual AIDS Curatorial Resident Ajamu|url=https://www.visualaids.org/blog/detail/introducing-2016-visual-aids-curatorial-resident-ajamu|website=Visual AIDS|accessdate=13 April 2016|date=17 February 2016}}</ref> * 2008 ''Outside Edge: a journey through black British lesbian and gay history'', [[Museum of Docklands]], London<ref name="MoL2008">{{cite web|title=Who works on an exhibition like Outside Edge?|url=http://blog.museumoflondon.org.uk/who-works-on-an-exhibition-like-outside-edge/|website=Museum of London - blog|accessdate=13 April 2016}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== * Bailey, David A., ed. (1995) ''Ajamu: Black Bodyscapes'', Camerawork, London. * Njami, Simon. (1994) ''Anthology of African Photography'', Edition Revue Noir * X, Ajamu, Campbell, Topher, & Stevens, Mary (2010). [http://journals.sfu.ca/archivar/index.php/archivaria/article/viewFile/13240/14558 Love and lubrication in the archives, or rukus!: a Black queer archive for the United Kingdom]. ''Archivaria, 68''(68)
==External links== * [http://ajamu-fineartphotography.co.uk/ Ajamu Fine Art Photography] official website * [http://rukus.org.uk/archives/ rukus! Federation] official website * [http://www.cityoflondon.gov.uk/things-to-do/london-metropolitan-archives/the-collections/Pages/rukus.aspx ''rukus! Black Lesbian Gay Bisexual Transgender Cultural Archive''] at [[London Metropolitan Archives]] * [http://www.aim25.ac.uk/cats/118/19869.htm ''rukus! Black Lesbian Gay Bisexual Transgender Cultural Archive'' finding aid] [[AIM25]]

page.title: Alexander Hall of the Winter Palace

revision.text:
[[Image:AlexanderHall.jpg|thumb|right|300px|The Alexander Hall, the Winter Palace, St Petersburg, by [[Eduard Hau]] (1861).]]
The '''Alexander Hall''' of the [[Winter Palace]], [[St Petersburg]], was created following the fire of 1837 by [[Alexander Briullov]].{{r|Petersburg}} The room commemorates the reign of [[Alexander I of Russia|Emperor Alexander I]] and the [[Napoleonic Wars]].
Decorated in an unusual [[Gothic Revival architecture|Gothic]]ised version of [[classic]]ism, the walls contain twenty-four [[medallion]]s commemorating Russia's victory over the French, created by the sculptor Count [[Fyodor Petrovich Tolstoy|Fyodor Tolstoy]].
==References== {{reflist|refs= <ref name="Petersburg"> {{cite web |title=State rooms of the Hermitage |url=http://www.saint-petersburg.com/museums/hermitage-museum/state-rooms/ |publisher=saint-petersburg.com |accessdate=13 May 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6YUlO9kH5?url=http://www.saint-petersburg.com/museums/hermitage-museum/state-rooms/ |archivedate=13 May 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }} </ref> }} <!--*[http://www.hermitagemuseum.org/html_En/08/hm89_0_1_41.html The State Hermitage Museum] retrieved 24 September 2008.--> [[Image:Alexanderhalllocation.jpg|thumb|left|175px|Location of the Alexander Hall within the Winter Palace]]
{{The Winter Palace}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Alexander Hall Of The Winter Palace}} [[Category:Hermitage Museum]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox organization | name = Anglo-Norman Text Society | abbreviation = ANTS | formation = 1937 | founder = [[Mildred Pope]] | founding_location = Manchester | status = Active | fields = [[Medieval studies]], [[Anglo-Norman language]], [[Anglo-Norman literature]], [[Textual criticism]] | leader_title = Presidents | leader_name = Ian Short, Tony Hunt | leader_title2 = Hon. Secretary | leader_name2 = Daron Burrows | leader_title3 = North American Treasurer | leader_name3 = Maureen Bolton | website = http://www.anglo-norman-texts.net }}
The '''Anglo-Norman Text Society''' is a [[text publication society]] founded in 1937 by Professor [[Mildred Pope|Mildred K. Pope]].<ref>http://www.anglo-norman-texts.net</ref> The founding aim of the society was to promote the study of [[Anglo-Norman language]] and [[Anglo-Norman literature]] by facilitating the publication of reliable scholarly editions of a broad range of texts of literary, linguistic, historical and legal value and interest. Based in the United Kingdom, the Society draws individual and institutional members from across the world.
==Publications== ===Annual Texts series=== The original series of publications launched by the Society was the Anglo-Norman Texts series, sometimes referred to as the Annual Texts series. The aim of this series was to produce an edition each year (or one volume of a multi-volume edition each year), yet while this rhythm has generally been maintained throughout the Society's history, unforeseen circumstances have on occasion led to minor delays or gaps in this schedule. The series has featured editions by some of the most renowned Anglo-Norman specialists of their time, including Mildred Pope, [[Dominica Legge|M. Dominica Legge]], Alexander Bell, Ronald C. Johnson, Anthony J. Holden, Brian Merrilees, Ian Short, Tony Hunt, and Delbert Russell.
===Plain Texts series=== The Annual Texts series was complemented by the launch of two additional series in 1983. The first of these was the Plain Texts series, which has the goal of providing a critical text predominantly for shorter works, but without the more detailed introduction and notes provided in the Annual Texts series.
===Occasional Publications series=== The second series was the Occasional Publications series, which, as the name suggests, has been reserved for publications which fall outside the remit of the other series. The first release in this series was a volume of essays compiled in memory of the Society's long-serving President, [[:de:T.B.W. Reid|T. B. W. Reid]]. The series has also featured Ruth Dean's ''Anglo-Norman Literature: a Guide to Texts and Manuscripts'', an indispensable successor to an earlier work with a similar remit by the Swedish scholar [[:sv:Johan Vising|Johan Vising]], and most recently Ian Short's ''Manual of Anglo-Norman'', building on Pope's monumental study of Anglo-Norman in the final section of her From Latin to Modern French, with Especial Consideration of Anglo-Norman (Manchester: Manchester University Press, 1934; revised reprints 1952 and 1956). It is also in this series that Holden, Gregory, and Crouch's edition of the ''History of William Marshal'' appeared, an account of the life and adventures of the famous [[William Marshal, 1st Earl of Pembroke]].
==References== <references />
[[Category:Anglo-Norman literature]] [[Category:Learned societies of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Text publication societies]]

page.title: Annla Gearra as Proibhinse Ard Macha

revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''Annla Gearra as Proibhinse Ard Macha''''', in English '''''The Short Annals of [[Armagh]]''''', is an Irish text contained in ''[[British Library]], [[Additional manuscripts]] 30512'', compiled c. 1460–75.
The ''Annala Gearra Ard Macha'' covers events in Irish history from the lifetime of [[Lóegaire mac Néill]] (died c. 462) to 1134 (''"In bliadhain post ec Muircertaig comarba Patraic'' {folio 40vb} ''& abdaine do gabail do Niall & ordned Mailmedoc hUi Morgair & rl—.''"). The manuscript was penned by [[Iollan Mac an Leagha]], a professional scribe.
==See also==
* [[Book of Armagh]] * [[Short Annals of Tirconaill]]
==References== * Manuscript source: London, British Library, Additional MS 30512, ff.39rb-40rb; for details see Robin Flower (ed.), Catalogue of Irish manuscripts in the British Library [formerly the British Museum], volume 2, 470–3, 490. * [[Gearóid Mac Niocaill]] (ed.), ''Ann[acute ]la Gearra as Proibhinse Ard Macha'', ''Seanchas Ardmhacha'' 3/2 (1958–9), pp. 337–40. * [[Eugene O'Curry]], ''Lectures on the manuscript materials of ancient Irish history'' (Dublin, 1861; repr. Dublin, 1878 and 1995). * [[Paul Walsh (priest)|Paul Walsh]], ''The dating of Irish annals'', Irish Historical Studies 2 (1941), pp. 355–75. * [[Gearóid Mac Niocaill]], ''The medieval Irish annals'' (Dublin: DIAS, 1975). * Daniel P. Mc Carthy, ''The Irish Annals: their genesis, evolution and history'' (Dublin 2008).
==External links==
* http://www.ucc.ie/celt/published/G100018/index.html
{{DEFAULTSORT:Annla Gearra Ard Macha}} [[Category:1470s books]] [[Category:15th-century history books]] [[Category:15th-century manuscripts]] [[Category:Irish-language literature]] [[Category:Medieval literature]] [[Category:Early Irish literature]] [[Category:Irish texts]] [[Category:Irish chronicles]] [[Category:Irish manuscripts]] [[Category:British Library additional manuscripts]] [[Category:Armagh (city)]] {{manuscript-stub}}

[[File:Apothecary Shop, Interior 2.jpg|thumb|Interior of the Apothecary Shop, located adjacent to the General Store at the Shelburne Museum.]] {{coord|4|22|35.94|N|73|13|52.62|W|region:US|display=title}} The '''Apothecary Shop''' is a building at the [[Shelburne Museum]] in [[Shelburne, Vermont]] that exhibits objects salvaged from [[New England]] pharmacies that were closing in the early decades of the 20th century. The main room contains dried herbs, spices, drugs, and labeled glass apothecary bottles from the nineteenth century, as well as early [[patent medicines]], medical equipment, [[cosmetics]], and a collection of barbers’ razors. The compounding room, with its brick hearth, copper distilleries, and percolators replicates an illustration found in [[Edward Parrish]]’s 1871 Treatise on Pharmacy.<ref>Parrish, Edward. Treatise on Pharmacy: Designed as a Text-book for the Student and a Guide for the Physician and Pharmacist. 4 ed. Henry C. Lea. Philadelphia: Henry C. Lea's Son & Co., 1884.</ref>
==History== In 1959 the [[Shelburne Museum]] constructed the ''Apothecary Shop'' as an addition to the ''General Store''. Inside the display shelves, pill press, and other professional tools create the appearance of an operating druggist’s shop between 1870 and 1900. The glass vessels displayed in the front windows are symbols of the [[apothecary]] trade: the red fluid represents [[arterial]] blood while the blue represents [[venous blood]]. Prior to the Civil War, druggists gathered and dried [[herbs]], primed them for medicinal use through the process of grinding or [[distillation]], then combined the prepared herbs with sugar, lard, alcohol and other substances to create tablets, ointments, and elixirs. While these practices continued into the late nineteenth century, druggists gradually responded to an ever-greater demand for patent medicines as customers began to prefer brightly labeled cure-alls to herbal remedies. Passage of the [[Pure Food and Drug Act]] in 1906 marked the beginning of the modern drugstore and the end of the [[apothecary]] shop.<ref>Shelburne Museum. 1993. Shelburne Museum: A Guide to the Collections. Shelburne: Shelburne Museum, Inc.</ref>
==References== <references />
==External links== * [http://www.shelburnemuseum.org/ Shelburne Museum website] {{Shelburne Museum Buildings}}
[[Category:Shelburne Museum]] [[Category:Medical museums in the United States]] [[Category:Pharmacy museums]] [[Category:Medical and health organizations based in Vermont]]

{{Infobox Newspaper | name = ''Arcade Herald'' | image = | caption = | type = Weekly | format = [[Broadsheet]], Digital | foundation = 1891 | ceased publication = | owners = Neighbor to Neighbor News, Inc. | publisher = Grant Hamilton | editor = Casey Dunlap | language = | political = | circulation = 5000 | headquarters = [[Wyoming County, New York|Wyoming County]], [[New York (state)|New York]], [[United States]] | oclc = | ISSN = | website = {{URL|https://www.arcadeherald.com/}} }}
The ''Arcade Herald'' is a publication of Neighbor to Neighbor News, Inc. that serves ten townships and two villages surrounding [[Arcade, New York]] in the United States.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.mondotimes.com/1/world/us/32/5511/16515|title=Arcade Herald newspaper - MondoTimes.com|website=www.mondotimes.com|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref> It is published on Thursdays. Estimated circulation is 5000.<ref name=":0" /> The current publisher is Grant Hamilton, with Casey Dunlap as editor.<ref name=":0" />
==History==
The ''Arcade Herald'' was established in 1891 as the ''Wyoming County Herald'' under publisher George Chase.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn86034975/|title=About Arcade Herald|last=|first=|date=|website=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers|publisher=Library of Congress|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=11 October 2018}}</ref> In 1895, Chase left town suddenly and did not return. The ''Herald'' was sold by the local sheriff in 1897 to Walter F. Arthurs on credit.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/24241017/retired_publisher_wyoming_county/|title=Walter F. Arthurs|last=|first=|date=17 Mar 1949|work=Democrat and Chronicle|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref> Chase later reformed<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/24241329/chase_turns_a_new_leaf/|title=Western New York in brief|last=|first=|date=13 Jul 1897|work=The Buffalo Times|access-date=}}</ref> and became vice president of the Wyoming County Press Association.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/24241380/wyoming/|title=Wyoming|last=|first=|date=22 May 1893|work=Democrat and Chronicle|access-date=}}</ref>
In 1899, the Republican members of the board of supervisors of Wyoming County designated the ''Herald'' as newspaper to publish the sessions laws,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/24241498/session_laws_wyoming_county/|title=Wyoming|last=|first=|date=23 Nov 1899|work=Democrat and Chronicle|access-date=}}</ref> and in 1916, it was so designated again.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BC8tAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA55&dq=%22wyoming+county+herald%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwixkYyK9OrdAhUhjFQKHbqzBXkQ6AEIJzAA#v=onepage&q=%22wyoming%20county%20herald%22&f=false|title=Journal of the Board of Supervisors of Wyoming County, New York|last=Supervisors|first=Wyoming County (N Y. ) Board of|date=1916|publisher=The Board|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=55|language=en}}</ref>
In 1927, the name of the newspaper was changed to the ''Arcade Herald''.<ref name=":1" /> In 1945, Arthurs sold the newspaper to Paul F. Dorris.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/24241607/arcade_herald_sold_1945/|title=Arcade Herald Sold|last=|first=|date=8 Mar 1945|work=Springville Journal|access-date=}}</ref> In 1969, the name was changed to the ''Tri-County Times''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn88074477/|title=About Tri-county times|last=|first=|date=|website=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers|publisher=Library of Congress|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> In 1981, the name was changed back to the ''Arcade Herald''.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83008298//|title=About Arcade Herald (1981-present)|website=chroniclingamerica.loc.gov|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref> In 1986, Kathleen L. Mason became the publisher.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/24241778/kathleen/|title=Hospital to Present Board Candidates|last=|first=|date=15 May 1986|work=Springville Journal|access-date=}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Newspapers published in New York (state)]] [[Category:Newspapers]]
#REDIRECT [[ASPRO chronology]] {{R to acronym}}{{R from alternative language|fr|en}}

{{Infobox person | name = Bill Mazer | birth_name=Morris Mazer | birth_date = November 2, 1920 | birth_place = [[Iziaslav, Ukraine|Iziaslav]], [[Ukraine]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2013|10|23|1920|11|2}} | death_place=[[Danbury, Connecticut]], U.S. | nationality = [[United States|American]] | known_for = ''Sports Extra'', "Amazin' Mazer" | occupation = Broadcaster | spouse = Dora "Dutch" Sudarsky Mazer | children = 2 daughters, 1 son | alma_mater = [[University of Michigan]] }}
'''Bill Mazer''' (born '''Morris Mazer'''; November 2, 1920 – October 23, 2013) was an [[United States|American]] television and radio personality. He won numerous awards and citations, including three [[National Sportscasters and Sportswriters Association]]'s Sportscaster of the Year awards for New York from 1964–66.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://nssafame.com/2011/04/01/new-york/ | title=New York Sportscaster Awards | work=[[National Sportscasters and Sportswriters Association]] | accessdate=August 1, 2012 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120917003307/http://nssafame.com/2011/04/01/new-york/ | archivedate=September 17, 2012 | df= }}</ref> Considered a New York institution in sports reporting,<ref>{{cite news| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=y-gCAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA46 | work=[[New York Magazine]] | first=Jeff| last=Greenfield| title='The 10 O'Clock News':It's Not Pretty, but It's Good| date=October 24, 1977|accessdate=August 17, 2012}}</ref> Mazer was inducted into the hall of fame for the Buffalo Broadcasters Association (1999), Buffalo Baseball (2000) and the [[National Jewish Sports Hall of Fame and Museum]] (1997). He is also recognized as the host of the first sports talk radio show in history that launched in March 1964 on [[WNBC (AM)]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.newsday.com/sports/columnists/neil-best/first-time-long-time-for-bill-mazer-1.2962262 | work=[[Newsday]] | first=Neil| last=Best| title=First time, long time for Bill Mazer| date=June 16, 2011|accessdate=August 1, 2012}}</ref>
Mazer earned the nickname "The A-Maz-In" for his deep knowledge of sports [[trivia]]. This was made evident while hosting his WNBC radio show in the 1960s.<ref>{{cite journal| url=http://www.chutzpahmag.com/archives/2558 | work=[[Chutzpah Magazine]] | first=Len| last=Carter| title=Speaking of Sports: 25 Of The Best Sportscasting Legends| date=July 20, 2012|accessdate=August 2, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.dailyfreeman.com/articles/2010/08/29/sports/doc4c79e0e721b6d450290183.txt| work=[[Daily Freeman]] | first=Stan| last=Fischler| title=Mazer still 'Amazin' sportscaster| date=August 29, 2010|accessdate=August 2, 2012}}</ref> Based on this, he wrote several sports trivia books, including ''Bill Mazer's Amazin' Baseball Book: 150 Years of Baseball Tales & Trivia'' published by [[Zebra Books]] in 1990.
==Background== Mazer's family left Kiev, emigrating before his first birthday. He grew up in [[Brooklyn, New York|Brooklyn]], [[New York (state)|New York]]. A graduate of [[Yeshiva University High School for Boys]], he received a BA at [[University of Michigan]] for premed<ref>{{cite news| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UQkZRpVYVH4C&pg=PA19 | work=[[New York Magazine]] | first=Stephen| last=Dubner| title=Still Amazin'| date=February 3, 1992|accessdate=August 17, 2012}}</ref> before being [[Conscription|drafted]]. During [[World War II]], he served the majority of his time in the [[United States Armed Forces|Armed Forces]]-[[Air Force]] Transport Command in the [[Asiatic-Pacific Theater|Pacific theatre]].
After returning home, he married Dora Sudarsky ("Dutch"), his pre-war sweetheart. They had three children. Their marriage lasted 50 years until Sudarsky's death from [[cancer]] on April 28, 1996. The [[New York Knicks|New York Knickerbockers]] observed a moment of silence during their May 1, 1996 Playoff game.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/30/sports/tv-sports-fox-is-playing-it-safe-with-nhl.html?pagewanted=2&src=pm | work=[[The New York Times]] | first=Richard| last=Sandomir| title=TV SPORTS;Fox Is Playing It Safe With N.H.L.| date=April 30, 1996|accessdate=August 17, 2012}}</ref> Mazer never remarried.
==Career==
===Early work=== Mazer's broadcasting career began in 1942, broadcasting in Grand Rapids, Michigan before joining the United States Military that same year.<ref name="Fischler">{{cite news| url=http://www.dailyfreeman.com/articles/2010/09/05/sports/doc4c8320cb9fbd3866154510.txt?viewmode=fullstory| work=[[Daily Freeman]] | first=Stan| last=Fischler| title=Mazer continues 'Amazin' career| date=September 5, 2010|accessdate=August 2, 2012}}</ref>
His career as a [[sportscaster]] began in [[Buffalo, New York]] in 1947, where he signed on as a sportscaster on [[WWKB|WKBW]].<ref name="Fischler"/> In 1947, he was also the commercial announcer on the [[CBS]] [[William L. Shirer]] [[Newscast]], as well as the commercial announcer for the [[soap opera]], ''[[When a Girl Marries]].'' By 1948, he had also become the sports director for [[WGR|WGR radio]] and served as principal sports anchor for [[WGRZ-TV|WGR-TV]] from the time that station signed on in 1954 through the early 1960s. Mazer dominated the airwaves in Buffalo, broadcasting the hockey and baseball Buffalo Bisons, the All-American Football Conference Buffalo Bills and Little 3 Basketball.<ref name="Simon">{{cite news| url=http://www.wkbw.com/sports/Former-Voice-of-the-Bisons-Bill-Mazer-Dies-at-92--229157091.html| work=[[ABC 7/wkbw.com]]| first=Mitch| last=Simon| title=Former "Voice of the Bisons," Bill Mazer, Dies at 92| date=October 24, 2013| accessdate=June 4, 2014| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140606222343/http://www.wkbw.com/sports/Former-Voice-of-the-Bisons-Bill-Mazer-Dies-at-92--229157091.html| archivedate=June 6, 2014| df=}}</ref> With years of [[play-by-play]] and [[sports]] commentary in Buffalo under his belt, Mazer arrived in [[New York City]] in 1964 when [[WNBC (AM)]] went to its first all-talk format. His show was one of the pioneer examples of the modern sports [[radio talk show|talk show]] in [[United States|America]].
After filling in for [[Hugh Downs]] on the [[NBC]] [[game show]] ''[[Concentration]]'', he was given his own show, ''[[Reach for the Stars (game show)|Reach for the Stars]]'', in January 1967, but the show was quickly cancelled. Mazer also filled in for segements of [[Monitor (NBC Radio)|Monitor]], even hosting on occasion.<ref>http://monitorbeacon.net/nbc-monitor/monitors-history/</ref>
===National sportscasting and announcing=== Mazer served as a [[color analyst]] and intermission host, working alongside [[Dan Kelly (sportscaster)|Dan Kelly]] on [[CBS]]' [[National Hockey League]] coverage from the late sixties until the early seventies, broadcasting the [[Stanley Cup playoffs]] a few times. [[Golf]] was another Mazer specialty on [[NBC]], including the [[U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]] and [[Bing Crosby]] tournaments in the mid-1960s. [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] used Mazer for its regional New York football lineup in the late 1960s. Mazer also did sideline reporting for CBS coverage of the [[NFL]] in the late 1960s.
During the 1960s and 1970s, Mazer did much [[voice-over]] [[Advertising|commercial]] work, from [[L&M Cigarettes]], [[Eastman Kodak|Kodak]], [[Ford]] automobiles to [[Trident]] chewing gum, among many others.
===WNEW-TV=== Mazer was a sportcaster at New York's [[WNYW|WNEW-TV]] ([[Metromedia]] Channel 5) for twenty years, ending in the early 1990s. He also co-hosted the program ''Sports Extra'', which originally teamed him up with [[Lee Leonard]] and then later with Brian Madden (1976–78), respectively. ''Sports Extra'' is also considered to have been the first "sports wrap-up" show of its kind.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.jewishsports.org/jewishsports/detail.asp?sp=11 | work=[[The National Jewish Sports Hall of Fame and Museum]] | title=Biography | date=April 6, 1997 | accessdate=August 3, 2012 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120314021045/http://www.jewishsports.org/jewishsports/detail.asp?sp=11 | archivedate=March 14, 2012 | df= }}</ref>
While doing sports for ''The 10 O'Clock News'' on WNEW in the late 1970s and '80s, he held a daily contest where a viewer would send in a question to "stump" Bill and would win a prize if he or she did. Usually the submitted question was asked by anchorman [[John Roland]].
===WFAN (1988-1991; 2007) and WEVD (1992-2001)=== Mazer hosted a [[WFAN]] sports show from [[Mickey Mantle]]'s restaurant from 1988 to 1991, and returned to the station on June 30, 2007 to host an hour-long show from 10–11 AM during the station's 20th anniversary celebration and reunion weekend. He was also a morning talk show host on [[WEPN (AM)|WEVD]], where he expanded to a comprehensive [[Liberalism|liberal]] talk format from 1992 to 2001. The show ended when WEVD was optioned to ABC's [[ESPN]] division and became sports station [[WEPN (AM)|WEPN]].<ref name="Blair">{{cite news|url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F50D10FF3A540C758EDDAF0894D9404482|title=Liberal Radio Mainstay May Sell to Make Way for ESPN|last=Blair|first=Jayson|date=26 June 2001|work=The New York Times|accessdate=11 November 2010}}</ref>
Bill Mazer has appeared on the [[Cable television|cable TV]] show ''The [[Leon Charney]] Report'', as well as minor parts in movies such as ''[[Eyewitness (1981 film)|Eyewitness]], [[Raging Bull]]'' and appearing in episodes of [[ESPN]] ''[[SportsCentury]]'' as an expert on sport figures including [[Gordie Howe]], [[Lawrence Taylor]] and [[Mickey Mantle]].
===WVOX-AM (2001 - 2009)=== Following his departure from WEVD in 2001, Mazer launched an afternoon interview program on [[WVOX]] in [[New Rochelle, New York]] from 3–6 PM EST (available via streaming from WVOX's website), with his son, Arnie Mazer, serving as [[Radio producer|producer]]. His last show on WVOX was aired August 3, 2009, ending his tenure at the station after nearly eight years.
===Death (2013)=== Mazer's death was reported on October 23, 2013 at the age of 92. He died at a hospital in Danbury, Connecticut.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/24/sports/bill-mazer-a-sports-fixture-of-new-york-radio-and-tv-dies-at-92.html?_r=0 | work=The New York Times | first=Richard | last=Goldstein | title=Bill Mazer, Sports Fixture in New York, Dies at 92 | date=October 23, 2013}}</ref>
==Bibliography== * '''Sports Trivia:''' ** {{cite book |title=The Sports Answer Book: from Bill Mazer's NBC Challenge round |year=1966 |isbn=0448054388}} ** {{cite book |title=The Answer Book Of Sports |year=1969 |isbn=0448033283}} ** {{cite book |title=The New Answer Book of Sports: Answers to Hundreds of Questions about the World of Sports |year=1982 |isbn=0448044749}} ** {{cite book |title=Amazin Bill Mazer's Football Trivia Book |year=1981 |isbn=0446907855}} ** {{cite book |title=Amazin Bill Mazer's Baseball Trivia Book |year=1981 |isbn=0446917842}} ** {{cite book |title=Bill Mazer's Amazin Baseball Book: 150 Years of Tales and Trivia from Baseball's Earliest Beginnings Down to the Present Day |year=1990|isbn=0821729470}}
==External links== *{{YouTube|7EHQXhtJgDk|Interview}} with [[Leon Charney]] on The Leon Charney Report

{{Infobox biodatabase | title = Biological Magnetic Resonance Data Bank | logo = [[File:BMRB logo.svg|90px]] | description = Repository of [[Nuclear magnetic resonance|NMR]] data from biological molecules | scope = NMR data from peptides, proteins, nucleic acids and other biologically relevant molecules | url = [https://www.bmrb.wisc.edu] | download = [ftp://ftp.bmrb.wisc.edu/pub/bmrb/] | license = Public domain | format= NMR-STAR 3.1 }} The '''Biological Magnetic Resonance Data Bank''' ('''BioMagResBank''' or '''BMRB''') is an [[Open access|open access]] repository of [[Nuclear magnetic resonance|nuclear magnetic resonance]] (NMR) spectroscopic data from [[Peptide|peptides]], [[Protein|proteins]], [[Nucleic acid|nucleic acids]] and other biologically relevant molecules.<ref name=Ulrich2008>{{cite journal |last1=Ulrich |first1=E.L. |last2=Akutsu |first2=H. |last3=Doreleijers |first3=J.F. |last4=Harano |first4=Y. |last5=Ioannidis |first5=Y.E. |last6=Lin |first6=J. |last7=Livny |first7=M. |last8=Mading |first8=S. |last9=Maziuk |first9=D. |last10=Miller |first10=Z. |last11=Nakatami |first11=E. |last12=Schulte |first12=C.F. |last13=Tolmie |first13=D.E. |last14=Wenger |first14=R.K. |last15=Yao |first15=H. |last16=Markley |first16=J.L. |date=2008 |title=BioMagResBank |url= https://academic.oup.com/nar/article/36/suppl_1/D402/2507998 |journal=Nucleic Acids Research |volume=36 |issue=suppl_1 |pages=D402-D408 |doi=10.1093/nar/gkm957 |access-date=28 December 2017 }}</ref> The database is operated by the [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]] and is supported by the [[United States National Library of Medicine|National Library of Medicine]]. The BMRB is part of the Research Collaboratory for Structural Bioinformatics<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Berman |first1=H.M. |last2=Westbrook |first2=J. |last3=Feng |first3=Z. |last4=Gilliland |first4=G. |last5=Bhat |first5=T.N. |last6=Weissig |first6=H. |last7= Shindyalov |first7=I.N. |last8=Bourne |first8=P.E. |date=2006 |title=Chapter 24.5. The Protein Data Bank, 1999- |url= http://it.iucr.org/Fa/ch24o5v0001/ |journal=International Tables for Crystallography |volume=F |pages=675-684 |doi=10.1107/97809553602060000722 |access-date=31 December 2017}}</ref> and, since 2006, it is a partner in the [[Worldwide Protein Data Bank]] (wwPDB).<ref name=Berman2007>{{cite journal |last1=Berman |first1=H. |last2=Henrick |first2=K. |last3=Nakamura |first3=H. |last4=Markley |first4=J.L. |date=2007 |title=The worldwide Protein Data Bank (wwPDB): ensuring a single, uniform archive of PDB data |url=https://academic.oup.com/nar/article/35/suppl_1/D301/1115659?searchresult=1 |journal=Nucleic Acids Research |volume=35 |issue=suppl_1 |pages=D301-D303 |doi= 10.1093/nar/gkl971 |access-date=31 December 2017 }}</ref> The repository accepts NMR spectral data from laboratories around the world and, once the data is validated, it is available online at the BMRB website. The database has also an ftp site, where data can be downloaded in the bulk.<ref name=Ulrich2008 /> The BMRB has two mirror sites, one at the Protein Database Japan (PDBj) at [[Osaka University]] and one at the Magnetic Resonance Research Center (CERM) at the [[University of Florence]] in Italy. The site at Japan accepts and processes data depositions.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia |last1=Ulrich |first1=E.L. |last2=Markley |first2=J.L. |editor-last=Roberts |editor-first=G.C.K. |encyclopedia=Encyclopedia of Biophysics |title=BMRB |url=https://link.springer.com/referenceworkentry/10.1007%2F978-3-642-16712-6_315 |access-date=2 January 2018 |year=2013 |publisher=Springer |location=Berlin, Heidelberg |doi=10.1007/978-3-642-16712-6_315}}</ref>
==Content== ===NMR spectral values and derived information=== The bulk of the data deposited at the BMRB consists of over 11,900 entries containing <sup>1</sup>H, <sup>13</sup>C, <sup>15</sup>N and <sup>31</sup>P assigned [[Nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy#Chemical shift|chemical shifts]] and [[Nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy#J-coupling|coupling constants]] of peptides, proteins and nucleic acids.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.bmrb.wisc.edu/search/query_grid/initial_grid.html |title=Current Content of the BMRB Archive |website=BMRB webpage |publisher=BMRB |access-date=2 January 2018}}</ref> Other derived data like [[Residual dipolar coupling|residual dipolar couplings]] (RDC), [[Spin-spin relaxation|relaxation parameters]], [[Nuclear Overhauser effect|NOE]] values, order parameters and [[Hydrogen-deuterium exchange#NMR spectroscopy|hydrogen exchange rates]] are also available. The database contains also a smaller amount of NMR data from carbohydrates, cofactors and ligands.<ref name=Ulrich2008 /> These data are crossreferenced to 3D structures in the [[Protein Data Bank|PDB]] when available. The NMR data are provided in the [[NMR-STAR file format]] and a number of format conversion tools are available at the site to convert files from NMR-STAR to other formats.<ref name=Ulrich2008 />
===NMR restraints grid=== The NMR restraints grid contains [[Nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy of proteins#Restraint generation|NMR restraints]] data from over 2500 proteins and nucleic acids collected from PDB depositions. The grid is constructed as four subsets of data:<ref name=Restraintsgrid>{{cite web |url= http://restraintsgrid.bmrb.wisc.edu/NRG/MRGridServlet |title=NMR Restraints Grid |website=BMRB website |publisher=BMRB |access-date=3 January 2018}}</ref> *The original NMR data: This subset contains data as found in depositions from the PDB. The data are in various different file formats and contain information about interatomic distances, [[Dihedral angle|dihedral angles]] and [[Residual dipolar coupling#Studies of biomolecular structure|RDC restraints]]. *Parsed restraints data: Most of the entries in the original data subset have been parsed into the NMR-star file format facilitating its access and use. This subset contains over 9,400 entries. *Converted restraints data (DOCR): Over 500 entries in the parsed subset have been converted to make the atom nomenclature consistent with the corresponding atomic coordinates. *Filtered restraints data (FRED): The data in the DOCR were filtered to remove duplicates, redundancies, inconsistencies and values that do not contribute to structure calculations.
===Time-domain data=== The BMRB has archived sets of raw time-domain data collected from NMR experiments carried out to calculate restraints and chemical shifts in peptides, proteins and nucleic acids. This collection contains over 200 entries and in many cases the [[Nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy of proteins#Data collection|pulse-sequences]] and the acquisition parameters used are also available.<ref name=Ulrich2008 />
===NMR spectral data from metabolomic compounds=== The BMRB hosts a database containing NMR spectral data from hundreds of [[Metabolomics|metabolomic]] compounds.<ref name=Ulrich2008 /> For most compounds, <sup>1</sup>H NMR, <sup>13</sup>C NMR, <sup>13</sup>C 90<sup>o</sup> [[Carbon-13 nuclear magnetic resonance#Distortionless enhancement by polarization transfer spectra|DEPT]], <sup>13</sup>C 135<sup>o</sup> DEPT, <sup>1</sup>H-<sup>1</sup>H [[Two-dimensional nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy#Total correlation spectroscopy (TOCSY)|TOCSY]] and <sup>1</sup>H-<sup>13</sup>C [[Two-dimensional nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy#Heteronuclear single-quantum correlation spectroscopy (HSQC)|HSQC]] are available.
===NMR statistics=== The BMRB provides a collection of NMR statistical data, including chemical shift distributions for individual atoms in [[Amino acid|amino acids]], [[Ribonucleotide|ribonucleotides]] and [[Deoxyribonucleotide|deoxyribonucleotides]]. The data are presented as interactive histograms and density plots.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bmrb.wisc.edu/ref_info/ |title=BMRB Chemical Shift Statistics |website=BMRB website |publisher=BMRB |access-date=3 January 2018}}</ref>
==Searches== ===The BMRB query Grid Interface=== The BMRB Query Grid Interface,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bmrb.wisc.edu/search/query_grid/initial_grid.html |title=BMRB Query Grid Interface |website=BMRB website |publisher=BMRB |access-date=3 January 2018}}</ref> allows to search the database by molecule type (peptide, protein, [[DNA]], [[RNA]], etc.), by data type (<sup>1</sup>H chemical shift, <sup>13</sup>C chemical shift, coupling constant, etc.), by PDB ID number and by BMRB accession number. ===FASTA search=== The BMRB site also contains a [[FASTA|FASTA]] search page where the database can be searched for matching nucleotide or peptide sequences.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bmrb.wisc.edu/data_access/fasta.shtml |title=BMRB FASTA search |website=BMRB website |publisher=BMRB |access-date=9 January 2018}}</ref> ===Search Archive page=== From the Search Archive page, it is possible to carry out searches by accession number, author, title, molecule name, and by ID number from other common databases. An Advanced Search option allows to carry out queries using a variety of search parameters like: entry information, citations, molecular assembly, experimental descriptions, NMR parameters, etc. The page contains also links to restraints and metabolomics searches<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bmrb.wisc.edu/search/ |title=Search BMRB |website=BMRB website |publisher=BMRB |access-date=9 January 2018}}</ref> ===Restraints search=== The NMR restraints grid can be searched by PDB or BMRB number,<ref name=Restraintsgrid /> and also by specific kinds of restraints, like torsion angle, distance, residual dipolar coupling, etc.<ref name=Ulrich2008 /> ===Metabolomics search=== Through the metabolomics search page.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bmrb.wisc.edu/metabolomics/ |title=Search BMRB metabolomics |website=BMRB website |publisher=BMRB |access-date=9 January 2018}}</ref> the database can be searched for specific compounds by name, molecular formula, molecular weight, ID number and molecular structure. It can be searched for entries with specific experimental conditions (solvent or field strength). The interface allows also to search for compounds with matching 1D or 2D NMR spectral peak lists.<ref name=Ulrich2008 /> ==Data deposition== The BMRB accepts depositions from research groups around the world. Deposition of data containing only NMR spectral data (with no coordinates data) is carried out through the BMRB site using the ADIT-NMR deposition system.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://deposit.bmrb.wisc.edu/ |title=BMRB Data Deposition Systems |website=BMRB website |publisher=BMRB |access-date=9 January 2018}}</ref> The types of data accepted include: NMR spectral parameters, relaxation data, and kinetic and thermodynamic data. Data must be entered in the NMR-STAR format, conversion from other common formats can be carried out using the STARch file converter provided at the site.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bmrb.wisc.edu/software/starch/ |title=Convert data file |website=BMRB website |publisher=BMRB |access-date=9 January 2018}}</ref> The site also contains an NMR-STAR template generator which produces formatted tables where NMR data can be entered.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bmrb.wisc.edu/software/tablegen/ |title=BMRB atom table generator |website=BMRB website |publisher=BMRB |access-date=9 January 2018}}</ref> NMR time-domain data is uploaded separately via ftp.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bmrb.wisc.edu/deposit/ftp_upload.html |title=Ftp upload instructions for NMR time-domain data |website=BMRB website |publisher=BMRB |access-date=9 January 2018}}</ref> The BMRB encourages depositors to validate their NMR data before deposition, using one of the validation tools available at the BMRB site, to check for inconsistencies and errors. .<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bmrb.wisc.edu/validate/ |title=Validation tools |website=BMRB website |publisher=BMRB |access-date=10 January 2018}}</ref> Once the data is deposited, it is checked for completeness, consistency and annotated, links to other databases are added and a BMRB accession number is generated. Deposition of data containing NMR and coordinates data is done through the OneDep deposition system of the wwPDB.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wwpdb.org/deposition/tutorial#nmr-specific-depositions |title=Tour of OneDep Deposition System |website=wwPDB website |publisher=PDB |access-date=9 January 2018}}</ref> Once the data is validated and accepted, it receives PDB and BMRB accession numbers.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.bmrb.wisc.edu/ Biological Magnetic Resonance Data Bank website] *[https://www.wwpdb.org/ Worldwide Protein Data Bank website] {{University of Wisconsin–Madison|state=collapsed}} [[Category:Biological databases]] [[Category:Public domain databases]] [[Category:Online databases]] [[Category:United States National Library of Medicine]] [[Category:University of Wisconsin–Madison]]

page.title: Comparison of open-source programming language licensing

revision.comment: F# has an MIT license, not Apache
revision.text:
{{unreferenced article|date=June 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} This is a '''comparison of open-source programming language licensing''' and related legal issues, covering all language implementations. Open-source programming languages are those that are released under [[open-source license]]s.
<!-- PLEASE: Keep this table sorted alphabetically by the "language" column. In each table, for each term, WP:LINK one instance only, usually the 1st, remove other WP:OVERLINK(s). --> {|class="wikitable sortable" border="1" style="font-size:90%;" |- !   Title    !Language !Implementation license !Additional information |- |''[[GNAT]]'' |[[Ada (programming language)|Ada]] |[[GNU General Public License#Version 3|GPLv3]] |FSF GNAT is GPLv3 with runtime exception, other versions have a GPL runtime. |- |''ALGOL 68G'' |[[ALGOL 68]] |[[GNU General Public License|GPL]] |- |''[[ALGOL 68RS|ELLA ALGOL 68]]'' |ALGOL 68 |[[Public domain]] or [[Crown copyright]] |- |''BWK awk'' |[[AWK]] |Custom |-
|''gawk'' |AWK |GPLv3 |- |''mawk'' |AWK |[[GNU General Public License#Version 2|GPLv2]] |- |''[[GNU Compiler Collection|GCC]]'' |[[C (programming language)|C]], [[C++]], [[Objective-C]], [[Assembly language|ASM]], [[Go (programming language)|Go]] |GPL |- |''[[Clang]], [[LLVM]]'' |C, C++, Objective-C |[[University of Illinois/NCSA Open Source License|NCSA]] |- |''[[OpenCOBOL]]'' |[[COBOL]] |GPL |- |''[[Mono (software)|Mono]]'' |[[C Sharp (programming language)|C#]], [[Visual Basic .NET]] |GPLv2, [[MIT License|MIT]] (X11), [[GNU Lesser General Public License|LGPLv2]] |- |''[[Erlang (programming language)|Erlang]]'' |Erlang |[[Erlang Public License|Erlang]], [[Apache License|Apache]] 2.0 |- |''[[Gforth]]'' |[[Forth (programming language)|Forth]] |GPLv3 |- |''[[Open Firmware]]'' |Forth |[[BSD licenses|BSD]] |- |''[[Pforth]]'' |Forth |Public domain |- |''[[FreeBASIC]]'' |[[BASIC]] |GPL |Inspired by and compatible with [[QBasic]]. |- |''[[Gambas]]'' |[[BASIC]] |GPL |Partially compatible with [[Visual Basic]] code. |- |''[[Harbour (software)|Harbour]]'' |[[Harbour (software)|Harbour]] |GPL |- |''[[Helium (Haskell)|Helium]]'' |[[Haskell (programming language)|Haskell]] |GPL {{Ecommerce}} A '''comparison shopping website''', sometimes called a '''price comparison website, Price Analysis tool, comparison shopping agent''', '''shopbot''' or '''comparison shopping engine''', is a [[vertical search engine]] that shoppers use to filter and compare [[product (business)|product]]s based on price, features, [[Review|reviews]] and other criteria. Most comparison shopping sites aggregate product listings from many different [[retailer]]s but do not directly sell products themselves, instead earning money from [[affiliate marketing]] agreements. In the [[United Kingdom]], these services made between £780m and £950m in revenue in 2005<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukprwire.com/Detailed/Computers_Internet/Shopping_Comparison_Engines_market_worth_120m-_140m_in_2005_says_E-consultancy_1648.shtml |title=Shopping Comparison Engines market worth £120m-£140m in 2005, says E-consultancy |publisher=Ukprwire.com |date=2006-04-12 |accessdate=2013-10-17}}</ref>{{Update after|2010|11|13}}. Hence, E-commerce accounted for an 18.2 percent share of total business turnover in the United Kingdom in 2012. Online sales already account for 13% of the total UK economy, and its expected to increase to 15% by 2017. There is a huge contribution of comparison shopping websites in the expansion of current E-commerce industry.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.phonesandyou.co.uk/blog/price-comparison-shopping-in-uk/|title=Price Comparison Shopping In UK|date=2016-08-17|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-08-19|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160912193044/http://www.phonesandyou.co.uk/blog/price-comparison-shopping-in-uk/|archivedate=2016-09-12|df=}}</ref>
== History == The first widely recognized comparison-shopping agent was BargainFinder, developed by [[Andersen Consulting]] (now [[Accenture]]). The team, led by researcher Bruce Krulwich, created BargainFinder in 1995 as an experiment and published it on-line without advance warning to the e-commerce sites being compared. The first commercial shopping agent, called Jango, was produced by [[Netbot]], a Seattle startup company founded by [[University of Washington]] professors [[Oren Etzioni]] and [[Daniel S. Weld]]; Netbot was acquired by the [[Excite]] portal in late 1997. Junglee, a Bay-area startup, also pioneered comparison shopping technology and was soon acquired by [[Amazon.com]]. Other early comparison shopping agents included pricewatch.com and killerapp.com. [[NexTag]] another entry into comparison shopping was named Times magazine world top 50 website in 2008.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://content.time.com/time/specials/2007/article/0,28804,1809858_1809955_1811450,00.html|title=50 Best Websites 2008 - TIME|date=2008-06-17|work=Time|access-date=2017-03-22|issn=0040-781X}}</ref>
Around 2010, the price comparison websites found their way to [[emerging markets]]. Especially [[South-East Asia]] has been a place for many new comparison websites.{{Citation needed|reason=Why 'especially South-East Asia?'|date=June 2017}} It started in 2010 with CompareXpress in [[Singapore]], and in the following years companies like Baoxian ([[China]]), [[Jirnexu]] ([[Malaysia]]), and AskHanuman ([[Thailand]]) followed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.postonline.co.uk/post/analysis/2319717/the-rise-of-price-comparison-sites-in-south-east-asia|title=The rise of price comparison sites in South East Asia|publisher=}}</ref>
Meanwhile, in developed markets, Google was accused of promoting Froogle and its replacement, the paid-placement-only [[Google Shopping]], over competitors in its search results, driving down traffic to other sites and driving some out of business.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/money/2017/08/04/541643346/episode-787-google-is-big-is-that-bad|title=Episode 787: Google Is Big. Is That Bad?|publisher=|accessdate=31 July 2018}}</ref> The [[European Commission]] began an investigation in 2010, which concluded in July 2017 with a €2.42 billion fine against the parent company Alphabet, and an order to change its practices within 90 days.<ref name="record_fine">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-40406542|title=Google hit with record $2.7bn EU fine|first=Leo|last=Kelion|date=27 June 2017|publisher=|accessdate=31 July 2018|via=www.bbc.com}}</ref>
== Comparison shopping agent ==
In the early development stage from 1995 to 2000, comparison shopping agents included not only price comparison but also rating and review services for online vendors and products. Altogether, there were three broad categories of comparison shopping services.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Wan | first1 = Y. | last2 = Menon | first2 = S. | last3 = Ramaprasad | first3 = A. | citeseerx = 10.1.1.57.9018 | title = A Classification of Product Comparison Agents | date = 2003 }}</ref>
Later, through mergers and acquisitions, many services were consolidated.
=== Services === Through 1998 and 1999, various firms developed technology that searched retailers websites for prices and stored them in a central database. Users could then search for a product, and see a list of retailers and prices for that product. Advertisers did not pay to be listed but paid for every click on a price. [[Streetprices]], founded in 1997, has been a very early company in this space; it invented price graphs and email alerts in 1998.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.streetprices.com/Electronics/Digital_Cameras/SP137588.html |title=Internet Archive Wayback Machine |date=8 May 1999 |publisher= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19990508004010/http://www.streetprices.com/Electronics/Digital_Cameras/SP137588.html |archivedate=8 May 1999 |df= }}</ref>
== Technology == Price comparison sites can collect data directly from merchants. Retailers who want to list their products on the website then supply their own lists of products and prices, and these are matched against the original database. This is done by a mixture of [[information extraction]], [[fuzzy logic]] and human labour.
Comparison sites can also collect data through a data feed file. Merchants provide information electronically in a set format. This data is then imported by the comparison website. Some third party businesses are providing consolidation of data feeds so that comparison sites do not have to import from many different merchants. Affiliate networks aggregate data feeds from many merchants and provide them to the price comparison sites. Many of the popular shopping websites provide direct affiliation to the customer who wants to become affiliate partner. They provide their own API to the affiliate partner to show their products with specifications to the affiliate partner's website. This enables price comparison sites to monetize the products contained in the feeds by earning commissions on click through traffic.{{cn|date=February 2018}}Other price comparison sites have deals with merchants and aggregate feeds using their own technology.{{cn|date=February 2018}}
In recent years, many ''off the shelf'' software solutions<ref>[http://www.comparisonfocus.com/shopping/shopping-price-comparison-scripts/ Shopping Price Comparison Scripts]. Retrieved May 7th, 2010.</ref> have been developed that allow website owners to take price comparison websites' inventory data to place retailer prices (context adverts) on their blog or content the only website. In return, the content website owners receive a small share of the revenue earned by the price comparison website. This is often referred to as the [[Revenue sharing|revenue share]]<ref>[http://www.pricespin.net/solutions.html 50/50 Revenue Share]. Retrieved September 3rd, 2010.</ref> business model.
Another approach is to [[Web crawler|crawl]] the web for prices. This means the comparison service scans retail web pages to retrieve the prices, instead of relying on the retailers to supply them. This method is also sometimes called 'scraping' information. Some, mostly smaller, independent sites solely use this method, to get prices directly from the websites that it is using for the comparison.
Yet another approach is to collect data is through [[crowdsourcing]]. This lets the price comparison engine collect data from almost any source without the complexities of building a crawler or the logistics of setting up data feeds at the expense of lower coverage comprehensiveness. Sites that use this method rely on visitors contributing pricing data. Unlike discussion forums, which also collect visitor input, price comparison sites that use this method combine data with related inputs and add it to the main database though collaborative filtering, artificial intelligence, or human labor. Data contributors may be rewarded for the effort through prizes, cash, or other social incentives.
However, some combination of these two approaches is most frequently used. Some search engines are starting to blend information from standard feeds with information from sites where product [[Stock-keeping unit|stock-keeping units (SKUs)]] are unavailable.
Empirical projects that assessed the functionality and performance of page-wise SSC engines (AKA bots) exist. These studies demonstrate that no best or parsimonious shopping bot exists with respect to price advantage.<ref>Serenko, A., and Hayes, J. (2009). [http://www.aserenko.com/papers/IJEB_Follow_up_Study.pdf Investigating the functionality and performance of online shopping bots for electronic commerce: A follow-up study. International Journal of Electronic Business 8(1): 1-15.]</ref><ref>Sadeddin K., Serenko, A. and Hayes, J. (2007). [http://www.aserenko.com/papers/IJEB_shopping_bots_1.pdf Online shopping bots for electronic commerce: The comparison of functionality and performance. International Journal of Electronic Business 5(6): 576-589.]</ref>
== Comparison of sites == {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ Common comparison features |- ! Site !! Website !! Browser Extension !! Mobile App !! Multiple Stores !! Comparison Between Stores !! Watchlist !! Forums !! Blog !! Specification Comparison !! API !! Offline Stores !! Price Per Unit !Price History !Price Alerts
|- |[[Nextag]] || Yes || No || Yes || Yes || Yes || No || No || No || No || No || No || No |Yes |Yes |- | [[PriceGrabber]] || Yes || No || Yes || Yes || Yes || No || No || No || No || Yes || No || No |No |No |- | [[Priceza]] || Yes ||Yes|| Yes || Yes || Yes || No || No || No || No || No || No || No |No |Yes |- | [[Shopping.com]] || Yes || No || No || Yes || Yes || Yes || No || No || No || No || No || No |No |No |- | [[Shopzilla]] || Yes || No || No || Yes || No || No || No || No || No || No || No || No |No |No |- | [[PriceOye]] || Yes || No || No || Yes || Yes || No || No || Yes || No || No || No || No |Yes |No |- |[[Pricena|Pricena.com]] |Yes |No |Yes |Yes |Yes |Yes |No |Yes |No |No |Yes |No |Yes |Yes |- | [[Yaoota Shopping Engine|Yaoota]] || Yes || No || Yes || Yes || Yes || No || No || Yes || No || No || Yes || No |No |No |- |}
Other competitors: * [[Google Shopping]] * [[bing.com]] * [[SuperMoney]]
== Business models == Price comparison sites typically do not charge users anything to use the site. Instead, they are monetized through payments from retailers who are listed on the site. Depending on the particular business model of the comparison shopping site, retailers either pay a flat fee to be included on the site, pay a fee each time a user clicks through to the retailer web site, or pay every time a user completes a specified action—for example, when they buy something or register with their e-mail address. Comparison shopping sites obtain large product data feeds covering many different retailers from affiliate networks such as LinkShare and Commission Junction. There are also companies that specialize in data feed consolidation for the purpose of price comparison and that charge users for accessing this data. When products from these feeds are displayed on their sites they earn money each time a visitor clicks through to the merchant's site and buys something. Search results may be sorted by the amount of payment received from the merchants listed on the website.<ref>Mulrean, Jennifer. [http://www.loginworks.com/informative/shopping-bots-really-work/ How shopping bots really work]</ref> large price comparison sites.<ref name="Online Shoppers Are Rooting for the Little Guy">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/16/business/some-shoppers-rebel-against-giant-web-retailers.html|title=Online Shoppers Are Rooting for the Little Guy|date=16 January 2012|work=The New York Times}}</ref>
In addition to comparing tangible goods, some sites compare prices of services, such as [[insurance]], credit cards, phone bills, and money transfer.
== Google Panda and price comparison == Like most websites, price comparison websites partly rely on search engines for visitors. The general nature of [[shopping]] focused price comparison websites is that, since their content is provided by retail stores, content on price comparison websites is unlikely to be absolutely unique. The table style layout of a comparison website could be considered by Google as "Autogenerated Content and Roundup/Comparison Type of Pages".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.webconfs.com/google-panda-article-40.php |title=Get Rid of Autogenerated Content and Roundup/Comparison Type of Pages (Point 4) |publisher=Webconfs.com |date= |accessdate=2013-10-17}}</ref> As of the 2011 updates to its search algorithm, known as [[Google Panda]], Google seems to have started considering these comparison sites to be of low quality.<ref name="seoptimise">{{cite web|url=http://white.net/noise/why-not-all-shopping-search-engines-have-lost-in-the-uk-google-pandaquality-update/ |title=Shopping Search Engines Have Lost in the UK Google Panda/Quality Update |publisher=White.net |date=2011-04-28 |accessdate=2013-10-17}}</ref>
== Niche players, fake test sites and fraud == Due to large affiliate network providers providing easily accessible information on large amounts of similar products from multiple [[Vendor|vendors]], in recent years small price comparison sites have been able to use technology that was previously only available to large price comparison sites.<ref name="Online Shoppers Are Rooting for the Little Guy"/>
This technology includes software and plugins aimed to standardize the typical processes involving price and product comparison. Without much resources it became possible for amateurs to build seemingly professional websites, mostly using the popular [[WordPress|Wordpress]] CMS. These small sites often rely on Google for their visitors, which are monetized using affiliate networks like Amazon.
The low content quality of typical niche sites, often bordering on spam and fraud, is a growing problem from the perspective of consumer protection and the quality of search engines. By playing the algorithm of search engine giant Google, it is possible to place low quality sites prominently in the search results.
Until recently the phenomenon of fake test or comparison websites had escaped public attention. An analysis by testbericht.de discovered that 34,6% of German search traffic related to product tests on the first page of google leads to fake test sites.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.testbericht.de/presse/fake-testseiten|title=Fake-Testseiten|website=www.testbericht.de|language=de|access-date=2017-02-03}}</ref> When a big German newspaper published a report about such a website<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.welt.de/wirtschaft/article161042965/Hueten-Sie-sich-vor-diesen-Warentest-Fake-Seiten.html|title=Verbraucherschutz: Hüten Sie sich vor diesen Warentest-Fake-Seiten - WELT|website=DIE WELT|access-date=2017-02-03}}</ref> and consumer protection organization sending out warning letters,<ref name=":0" /> observers started to note a sense of panic in the industry, with site owners changing or deleting the content in question.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.kritzelblog.de/nischenseitenchallenge/fakefritz-abmahnungen-bei-fake-test-seiten/|title=Abmahnungen gegen Fake-Test-Nischenseiten|date=2017-01-11|newspaper=Kritzelblog|language=de-DE|access-date=2017-02-03}}</ref> Amazon, being the biggest player in the affiliate market, declined to comment on the matter.<ref name=":1" />
Deceptive comparison sites give the impression of testing a product thoroughly. In reality, the tests are just an aggregation of freely available information, often leading to the most expensive products being recommended. This in turn increases the commission rate the site owners earn for the recommended products.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.idealo.de/magazin/2017/01/11/verbraucherschuetzer-warnen-vor-fake-testseiten-im-internet/|title=Verbraucherschützer warnen vor Fake-Testseiten im Internet|date=2017-01-11|newspaper=idealo Magazin|language=de-DE|access-date=2017-02-03}}</ref>
== Google EU Court Case ==
In 2017, the [[European Commission]] fined Google €2.42BN for allegedly monopolising the CSE market<ref>{{cite web|url=http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_IP-17-1784_en.htm|title=European Commission - PRESS RELEASES - Press release - Antitrust: Commission fines Google €2.42 billion for abusing dominance as search engine by giving illegal advantage to own comparison shopping service|website=europa.eu|accessdate=31 July 2018}}</ref>. [[Google]] released a statement that the European Commission's assessment will be appealed<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=14644284|title=Google's response to the European Commission fine - Hacker News|website=news.ycombinator.com|accessdate=31 July 2018}}</ref>. Google will review the formal decision, but expects that it will accrue the fine in the second quarter of 2017<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1652044/000119312517214148/d411078d8k.htm|title=8-K|website=www.sec.gov|access-date=2017-06-29}}</ref>.
== See also == * [[Discovery shopping]] * [[Gasoline price website]] * [[Consumer switching]]
== References == {{Reflist|2}} * Doorenbos, B; Etzioni, O; Weld, D. ''[http://portal.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=267658.267666&preflayout=tabs A scalable comparison-shopping agent for the World-Wide Web]'', AGENTS '97 Proceedings of the first international conference on Autonomous agents CM New York, NY, USA 1997 * Clark, D. ''[http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/Xplore/login.jsp?url=/iel5/2/17784/00820034.pdf?arnumber=820034 Shopbots become agents for business change]'', IEEE Computer, Vol. 33, Issue 2, 2000
